author: HCAndersen
text: IT was the month of May.

author: HCAndersen
text: The wind still blew cold; but from bush and tree, field and flower, came the welcome sound, "Spring is come."

author: HCAndersen
text: Wild-flowers in profusion covered the hedges.

author: HCAndersen
text: Under the little apple-tree, Spring seemed busy, and told his tale from one of the branches which hung fresh and blooming, and covered with delicate pink blossoms that were just ready to open.

author: HCAndersen
text: The branch well knew how beautiful it was; this knowledge exists as much in the leaf as in the blood; I was therefore not surprised when a nobleman's carriage, in which sat the young countess, stopped in the road just by.

author: HCAndersen
text: She said that an apple-branch was a most lovely object, and an emblem of spring in its most charming aspect.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the branch was broken off for her, and she held it in her delicate hand, and sheltered it with her silk parasol.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they drove to the castle, in which were lofty halls and splendid drawing-rooms.

author: HCAndersen
text: Pure white curtains fluttered before the open windows, and beautiful flowers stood in shining, transparent vases; and in one of them, which looked as if it had been cut out of newly fallen snow, the apple-branch was placed, among some fresh, light twigs of beech.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was a charming sight.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the branch became proud, which was very much like human nature.

author: HCAndersen
text: People of every description entered the room, and, according to their position in society, so dared they to express their admiration.

author: HCAndersen
text: Some few said nothing, others expressed too much, and the apple-branch very soon got to understand that there was as much difference in the characters of human beings as in those of plants and flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: Some are all for pomp and parade, others have a great deal to do to maintain their own importance, while the rest might be spared without much loss to society.

author: HCAndersen
text: So thought the apple-branch, as he stood before the open window, from which he could see out over gardens and fields, where there were flowers and plants enough for him to think and reflect upon; some rich and beautiful, some poor and humble indeed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Poor, despised herbs," said the apple-branch; "there is really a difference between them and such as I am.

author: HCAndersen
text: How unhappy they must be, if they can feel as those in my position do!

author: HCAndersen
text: There is a difference indeed, and so there ought to be, or we should all be equals."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the apple-branch looked with a sort of pity upon them, especially on a certain little flower that is found in fields and in ditches.

author: HCAndersen
text: No one bound these flowers together in a nosegay; they were too common; they were even known to grow between the paving-stones, shooting up everywhere, like bad weeds; and they bore the very ugly name of "dog-flowers" or "dandelions."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Poor, despised plants," said the apple-bough, "it is not your fault that you are so ugly, and that you have such an ugly name; but it is with plants as with men,- there must be a difference."

author: HCAndersen
text: "A difference!" cried the sunbeam, as he kissed the blooming apple-branch, and then kissed the yellow dandelion out in the fields.

author: HCAndersen
text: All were brothers, and the sunbeam kissed them- the poor flowers as well as the rich.

author: HCAndersen
text: The apple-bough had never thought of the boundless love of God, which extends over all the works of creation, over everything which lives, and moves, and has its being in Him; he had never thought of the good and beautiful which are so often hidden, but can never remain forgotten by Him,- not only among the lower creation, but also among men.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sunbeam, the ray of light, knew better.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You do not see very far, nor very clearly," he said to the apple-branch.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Which is the despised plant you so specially pity?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "The dandelion," he replied.

author: HCAndersen
text: "No one ever places it in a nosegay; it is often trodden under foot, there are so many of them; and when they run to seed, they have flowers like wool, which fly away in little pieces over the roads, and cling to the dresses of the people.

author: HCAndersen
text: They are only weeds; but of course there must be weeds.

author: HCAndersen
text: O, I am really very thankful that I was not made like one of these flowers."

author: HCAndersen
text: There came presently across the fields a whole group of children, the youngest of whom was so small that it had to be carried by the others; and when he was seated on the grass, among the yellow flowers, he laughed aloud with joy, kicked out his little legs, rolled about, plucked the yellow flowers, and kissed them in childlike innocence.

author: HCAndersen
text: The elder children broke off the flowers with long stems, bent the stalks one round the other, to form links, and made first a chain for the neck, then one to go across the shoulders, and hang down to the waist, and at last a wreath to wear round the head, so that they looked quite splendid in their garlands of green stems and golden flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the eldest among them gathered carefully the faded flowers, on the stem of which was grouped together the seed, in the form of a white feathery coronal.

author: HCAndersen
text: These loose, airy wool-flowers are very beautiful, and look like fine snowy feathers or down.

author: HCAndersen
text: The children held them to their mouths, and tried to blow away the whole coronal with one puff of the breath.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had been told by their grandmothers that who ever did so would be sure to have new clothes before the end of the year.

author: HCAndersen
text: The despised flower was by this raised to the position of a prophet or foreteller of events.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do you see," said the sunbeam, "do you see the beauty of these flowers? do you see their powers of giving pleasure?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, to children," said the apple-bough.

author: HCAndersen
text: By-and-by an old woman came into the field, and, with a blunt knife without a handle, began to dig round the roots of some of the dandelion-plants, and pull them up.

author: HCAndersen
text: With some of these she intended to make tea for herself; but the rest she was going to sell to the chemist, and obtain some money.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But beauty is of higher value than all this," said the apple-tree branch; "only the chosen ones can be admitted into the realms of the beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
text: There is a difference between plants, just as there is a difference between men."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the sunbeam spoke of the boundless love of God, as seen in creation, and over all that lives, and of the equal distribution of His gifts, both in time and in eternity.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is your opinion," said the apple-bough.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then some people came into the room, and, among them, the young countess,- the lady who had placed the apple-bough in the transparent vase, so pleasantly beneath the rays of the sunlight.

author: HCAndersen
text: She carried in her hand something that seemed like a flower.

author: HCAndersen
text: The object was hidden by two or three great leaves, which covered it like a shield, so that no draught or gust of wind could injure it, and it was carried more carefully than the apple-branch had ever been.

author: HCAndersen
text: Very cautiously the large leaves were removed, and there appeared the feathery seed-crown of the despised dandelion.

author: HCAndersen
text: This was what the lady had so carefully plucked, and carried home so safely covered, so that not one of the delicate feathery arrows of which its mist-like shape was so lightly formed, should flutter away.

author: HCAndersen
text: She now drew it forth quite uninjured, and wondered at its beautiful form, and airy lightness, and singular construction, so soon to be blown away by the wind.

author: HCAndersen
text: "See," she exclaimed, "how wonderfully God has made this little flower.

author: HCAndersen
text: I will paint it with the apple-branch together.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every one admires the beauty of the apple-bough; but this humble flower has been endowed by Heaven with another kind of loveliness; and although they differ in appearance, both are the children of the realms of beauty."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the sunbeam kissed the lowly flower, and he kissed the blooming apple-branch, upon whose leaves appeared a rosy blush.
